raw_text:
Healey targets England comeback
 
 Leicester wing Austin Healey hopes to use Sunday's return Heineken Cup clash with Wasps as a further springboard to an England recall for the Six Nations.
 
 Healey, who won 51 caps prior to the 2003 World Cup, has been in good form in the Tigers' resurgence this season. "I definitely still have ambitions to play for England," Healey told the BBC. "We will have to see what happens after the previous (autumn) Tests but when I look at the current squad I definitely feel there is a place there for me." Healey, who has also played both half-back positions and full-back during his career, has reverted to the wing, where he won most of his England caps. After recovering from a trapped nerve in his back sustained at the end of September, the 31-year-old is relishing his role in the Tigers revival. "I had six weeks out but fortunately I have resumed the sort of form I had before," he said.
 
 "I am basically playing where it best suits Leicester. Obviously I can play scrum-half, fly-half or full-back at a moment's notice. "But playing on the wing actually gives me a bigger free role to come in where I am not expected and influence things." That has been apparent in parts one and two of the Wasps-Leicester trilogy in recent weeks. First, Healey came off his flank with an angled run to score an injury-time try that earned the Tigers a 17-17 draw in their Premiership meeting on 21 November. Then, in the first of their Heineken cup double header last Sunday, Healey slotted in at stand-off and delivered a superb cross-kick for Martin Corry to score the Tigers' third try. "I caught 'Cozza's' eye a couple of phases before that and was hoping to get it to him on the full, but fortunately even with the bounce he managed to score," Healey recalled.
 
 Healey, twice a Heineken Cup winner, believes last Sunday's match was "up there" with some of the biggest club contests he has played in. "It was a very intense occasion and a very destructive game," he recalled. "There was not a huge amount of rugby played but it was a great game to be involved in. "After about 15 minutes I thought we might stride away with it but Wasps really came back into it and in the last couple of minutes it could have gone either way."
 
 The same outcome this Sunday would put Leicester in pole position to top their Heineken pool with a home game against Biarritz and away trip to Calvisano to come. But Healey insists the Tigers must summon the same desire if they are to deliver the knockout blow in what has been dubbed "rugby's version of Rocky II". "There was a lot of satisfaction in the dressing room aftewards but it is really only a case of a job half done," he added. "It was the first of a two-leg trip and if we lose at Welford Road it will negate all the positives we can take from result. "I think it came down to who wanted it more and in the end I think we did. We have got to show the same desire again this week."
llama3.2:1b: Leicester wing Austin Healey hopes Sunday's return to action against Wasps will boost England's chances for a comeback bid, with Healey having played an injury-time try and a crucial cross-kick in his team's Heineken Cup match earlier this season. He is targeting a return to the England squad after recovering from a trapped nerve in his back sustained at the end of September.
llama3.2:3b: Austin Healey hopes to use Sunday's Heineken Cup match with Wasps as a springboard for an England recall, citing his recent form with Leicester and wanting to play where it best suits him, including on the wing.
gemma2:2b: Austin Healey aims to secure a return to the England squad for the Six Nations, using his form with Leicester as leverage.  He is enjoying playing on the wing, where he has historically excelled, and believes the recent Heineken Cup match against Wasps was an example of his contributions. The Tigers are still in contention for top spot in their pool, but Healey emphasizes that a repeat performance this Sunday will be crucial to achieving victory.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Healey targets England comeback: Healey hopes his return Heineken Cup clash with Wasps will be a springboard to an England recall for the Six Nations, and has been in good form since he returned from injury at the end of September. Healey is in the wing position after recovering from a back injury, while playing both half-back positions during his career. He's currently relishing his role as Leicester's captain in the Tigers' revival. His former team mate Martin Corry scored for Leicester in their Premiership match, and Healey believes he can get on Corry's radar if he scores. Healey has been involved in several Heineken Cup matches this season, including last Sunday's win over Wasps. If Leicester are to top their pool, Healey says they need to show the same desire as a comeback in what would be their first away game against Welford Road.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Leicester wing Austin Healey aims to impress England selectors with his Heineken Cup form, hoping for an England recall before the Six Nations. Having won 51 caps prior to the World Cup in 2003, he is eager to play alongside current squad members and believes his role as a wing could lead to an inclusion. After recovering from a back injury, Healey is relishing Leicester's resurgence and has reverted to the wing position where he excelled before winning most of his England caps. Last Sunday's Heineken Cup match against Wasps was described as one of the toughest club contests he had played in, with strong performances by both sides potentially determining the top pool in the tournament. Healey emphasizes that while the result could not have been different, they must maintain their desired level to secure a victory and continue leading their group.
qwen2.5:3b: Austin Healey, a Leicester wing player aiming for England recall, has been in excellent form since recovering from a back injury. The 31-year-old played well in recent matches with Wasps and believes last Sunday's match was among his best club contests. He wants to maintain the same intensity and desire against Biarritz at home this Sunday to lead Leicester to top their Heineken Cup pool.
opencoder:1.5b:
Healey targets England's comeback

Leicester plans to use Sunday's cup clash as a springboard for an England recall

Healey, a footballer from England who has won 51 caps since the World Cup, is in good form in the Tigers' recovery. "I feel confident enough to continue my ambition," he told the BBC. "I will be able to see what happens after this season but I am certain there is a place for me." Healey insists he can move forward with his current squad, ready to reshape and redefine England's footballing experience.

After recovering from a nerve injury on September 30, he enjoyed an exciting role in the Tigers' revival. He scored two tries, one during the autumn Tests and another at Wasps, and the Tigers secured a draw at Premiership matches. Despite the injury, Healey continued to play as a forward, ready for any opportunity to influence England.

The Tigers have also shown strong anticipation of a possible double-header match with Healey this Sunday, adding to their enthusiasm. This was a test of his exceptional rugby ability and confidence in his footballing acumen. Healey managed to score a try on Sunday's match, which earned the Tigers' first European Cup title.

Healey is now a part of his family, having made it a dream he has always dreamed of playing for England. Despite being new to the sport, he continues to inspire and challenge, ready to take on challenges and shape the future of footballing.
